conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, and their shape and size depend on the positions of the light source, object, and surface.
Closer light source results in larger, more distorted shadows; farther light source results in smaller, more accurate shadows.
Moving the light source upward increases the distance between the light source and objects, affecting shadow size and position.
Shadows become smaller as the light source moves upward because light rays become more parallel.
Shadows move closer to objects as the light source moves upward due to the angle of light rays becoming more perpendicular.
Shadow A (Apple) will become smaller and move closer to the apple.
Shadow B (Flag) will become smaller and move closer to the flag.
Shadow C (Glass) will become smaller and move closer to the glass.
Shadow D (Chicken Leg) will become smaller and move closer to the chicken leg.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller and move closer to their respective objects when the light source moves upward.
